title: Jim Simpson (sportscaster)
text:
James Shores Simpson (December 20, 1927 – January 13, 2016) was an American <a href="sportscaster">sportscaster</a>, known for his smooth delivery as a <a href="play-by-play">play-by-play</a> man and his versatility in covering many different sports. In <a href="1997%20in%20sports">1997</a>, he won the <a href="Sports%20Lifetime%20Achievement%20Award">Sports Lifetime Achievement Award</a>, and in <a href="2000%20in%20sports">2000</a> he was inducted into the <a href="National%20Sportscasters%20and%20Sportswriters%20Association">National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association</a> <a href="NSSA%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Hall of Fame</a>.
Career.
Jim Simpson was born in Washington, D.C., and grew up in nearby <a href="Chevy%20Chase%2C%20Maryland">Chevy Chase, Maryland</a>. He began his broadcasting career with a short-lived radio show, "Hunting and Fishing with Jimmy Simpson", when he was 15. He attended <a href="George%20Washington%20University">George Washington University</a> and served in the <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard">Coast Guard</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Navy%20Reserve">Navy Reserve</a>. After several jobs in radio, he began working in television in Washington in 1949. 
In the early 1950s, he shared a half-hour news program at Washington's <a href="WUSA%20%28TV%29">WTOP</a>-TV with another TV newcomer, <a href="Walter%20Cronkite">Walter Cronkite</a>, the future anchor of the "<a href="CBS%20Evening%20News">CBS Evening News</a>". He joined NBC's <a href="owned-and-operated">owned-and-operated</a> Washington station, <a href="WRC-TV">WRC-TV</a>, in 1955. Simpson broadcast <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> <a href="basketball">basketball</a> games in the early 1960s and worked as a sports reporter at WRC-TV. 
NBC Sports.
Eventually he would broadcast many sports at <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC</a>, including <a href="NFL%20on%20NBC">football</a>, <a href="College%20Basketball%20on%20NBC">basketball</a>, <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">baseball</a>, <a href="Tennis%20on%20NBC">tennis</a>, and <a href="Golf%20Channel%20on%20NBC">golf</a>. For much of the 1960s and 1970s he was generally considered the network's number two play-by-play announcer, behind only <a href="Curt%20Gowdy">Curt Gowdy</a>. He was in <a href="New%20Haven%2C%20Connecticut">New Haven, Connecticut</a> on November 22, 1963, to do the annual <a href="Harvard%E2%80%93Yale%20football%20rivalry">Harvard-Yale football game</a> with <a href="Lindsey%20Nelson">Lindsey Nelson</a> and Terry Brennan, when word came of the assassination of <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a>. Simpson was quoted as saying to Nelson as they walked through the tunnel of the <a href="Yale%20Bowl">Yale Bowl</a>, "We will remember this walk and this moment for a long, long, time." His work on <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> (and later <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">American Football Conference</a>) telecasts for NBC is perhaps what he is best remembered for. 
In 1966, Simpson and <a href="Bill%20Cullen">Bill Cullen</a> (who at the time, along with Simpson hosted a sports <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> called "NBC Sports in Action"), were the between-periods co-hosts for <a href="NHL%20on%20NBC">NBC</a>'s <a href="1966%20Stanley%20Cup%20Finals">Stanley Cup Finals</a> broadcasts. It marked the first time that the Stanley Cup Finals were broadcast on American network television. It was also the first time that hockey games were broadcast on network television in <a href="color%20television">color</a>. The <a href="Hockey%20Night%20in%20Canada">CBC</a> would follow suit the following year.
On January 15, 1967, Simpson (along with former quarterback <a href="George%20Ratterman">George Ratterman</a>) called <a href="Super%20Bowl%20I">Super Bowl I</a> for <a href="NFL%20on%20NBC%20Radio">NBC Radio</a>. He also called several <a href="World%20Series">World Series</a> for <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC%20Radio">NBC Radio</a>, as well as numerous <a href="Orange%20Bowl">Orange Bowl</a> games, the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">1966 FIFA World Cup Final</a> (via tape delay), and several <a href="Olympics%20on%20NBC">Olympic Games</a> for NBC television.
ESPN.
In <a href="1979%20in%20television">1979</a>, after Week 2 of the <a href="1979%20NFL%20season">NFL season</a>, the fledgling <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> cable sports network brought Simpson on board to provide some needed credibility with sports fans. Simpson broadcast the <a href="http%3A//findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4196/is_20061110/ai_n16848468">first NCAA basketball game</a> the network televised, with flamboyant <a href="Dick%20Vitale">Dick Vitale</a> as the <a href="color%20commentator">color man</a>. Vitale <a href="http%3A//findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1208/is_10_228/ai_114086625">credits</a> Simpson with helping him develop as a sportscaster. Simpson also called <a href="United%20States%20Football%20League%20on%20television">USFL</a>, <a href="NBA%20on%20ESPN">NBA</a>, <a href="ESPN%20College%20Football">college football</a>, and <a href="College%20World%20Series">College World Series</a> games for ESPN, in <a href="1988%20Baltimore%20Orioles%20season">1988</a> called the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>' local telecasts on <a href="WMAR-TV">WMAR-TV</a> (the NBC affiliate at the time), and called <a href="figure%20skating">figure skating</a> at the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics">1992</a> and <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">1994</a> <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a> for <a href="Olympics%20on%20TNT">TNT</a>.
After his sportscasting days Simpson retired to <a href="St.%20Croix">St. Croix</a>, <a href="Virgin%20Islands">Virgin Islands</a>. Among other firsts he was the initial U.S. sportscaster to appear live via satellite from <a href="Asia">Asia</a>, and he was involved in the first American sportscast using <a href="instant%20replay">instant replay</a> technology. In <a href="2005%20in%20television">2005</a>, ESPN brought Simpson back from retirement to do play-by-play for a series of college basketball games in a "turn back the clock" format on the <a href="ESPN%20Classic">ESPN Classic</a> network. He died on January 13, 2016, in Scottsdale, Arizona at the age of 88.
